text.p: The following are some of the leading stories in Finnish papers this morning.
- Finnish birth rate has fallen for two consecutive years, statistics show.
- Finance Minister Sauli Niinisto attacks opposition Centre Party in parliament dabate, saying it wants government budgetary expenditure to be upped by 2.5 billion markka next year.
- Parliament unanimously passed a law allowing employers in the service sector to use more part-time workers. @
- Finland, Sweden and Denmark will on Thursday sign the Schengen agreement which abolishes passport checks between countries in the pact.
- Finland puts its emphasis in bilateral development projects funding on democracy and human rights.
- Companies financing costs fall as banks compete, says study by industry lobby TT, Bank of Finland and ministry of trade.
- Finland is Europe's second largest borrower -- not a good position considering Europe's general weakeness, Finance Minister Sauli Niinisto says. @
- Finnair and Air Botnia have seamless cooperation in domestic air traffic and the two say they do not compete.
- Bank of Finland's parliamentary supervisors should monitor also the financial supervision Rata, finance ministry committee proposes.
- Finland to allocate an extra 1.5 billion markka to research and development. This will lift state R&D spending to 2.9 percent of GDP by the turn of the millenium, which is global top level. @
- Weaker unity in the government coalition was reflected in parliament debate over next year's budget.
- Finnish freemason embezzled half a million markka from the fraternity's funeral fund.

- Contrary to what official statistics suggest, alcohol consumption has increased, researcher says. Last year, consumption was 8.5 litres of absolute alcohol per inhabitant though official estimates put it at 6.6 litres.
